Title: Developing a mineral deposit exploration project using legacy data and machine learning
Description:
In this project, students will work in a team to enter a global mineral exploration challenge (the Frank Arnott Challenge): https://www.pdac.ca/members/students/faa/about-the-award

The team will select an area and be given geologic, geophysical, and geochemical datasets that they will use to identify the most prospective subregion for mineral exploration. They will use these data to identify areas prospective for exploration for mineral deposits. They will then develop a presentation that will outline the area's they have selected and argue why these areas were chosen.
AI_Description: Students will work in teams to analyze geologic, geophysical, and geochemical data to identify prospective mineral exploration areas and present their findings in the Frank Arnott Challenge.
Student Roles: Students will fill roles depending on their academic background; for example, geology students will work with geophysics students to model the 3D geology of the area and its corresponding potential mineralization, while data science students will work with geoscience students to use supervised & unsupervised machine learning to identify mineralization. Business or mining engineering students could focus on determining the most economic subregions, by considering the balance between the value of specific minerals and the costs of developing a mine. Together, these students will work together to develop a robust exploration target. The team will meet with the supervising professors twice a week (typically in-person, but potentially over Zoom if other summer commitments arise).
AI_Student Roles: Students will take on roles based on their academic backgrounds, collaborating across geology, geophysics, data science, and business to model 3D geology, apply machine learning, and assess economic viability, with regular meetings with supervising professors.
Academic Outcomes: Students will obtain firsthand experience in target generation, a skill that is usually developed in professional settings when working in industry. Students will also get hands-on experience using Leapfrog and Geosoft, which are two commonly used software programs in the mineral exploration industry. Finally, students will get experience writing exploration proposals and giving presentations for investors, which is another important skill in real-world mineral exploration settings.
AI_Academic Outcomes: Students will gain hands-on experience in target generation, industry-standard software (Leapfrog and Geosoft), and developing exploration proposals and presentations for investors.
Training & Mentorship: During the course students will gain mentorship from both Swidinsky and Gregory but also graduate students who will be working on the same target generation project. This will provide multiple levels of mentorship and help students to broaden their network. Additionally, the contest has industry mentors who will be able to provide additional, practical mentorship. This will further aid students in extending their mentorship. Lastly, the end product will be assessed by a team of ~6 expert judges who will give a broad level of feedback for the students.
AI_Training & Mentorship: Students will receive mentorship from professors Swidinsky and Gregory, graduate students, and industry professionals, with additional feedback from expert judges.
Selection Criteria: Students will be selected based on a combination of GPA and how their unique expertise in geophysics, geology, geochemistry, machine learning, mining engineering or business (or any other relevant field) will be able aid in the team.
AI_Selection Criteria: Students will be selected based on GPA and their expertise in geophysics, geology, geochemistry, machine learning, mining engineering, business, or other relevant fields to enhance the team.

Title: "Neurobiology of motivation" and "Neural stem cells"
Description:
Motis
Our data have suggested that opiates work on a specific pathway out of the ventral midbrain to produce reward. However, when we tried to optogenetically stimulate this paper in a tonic matter, we observed aversions for the stimulation. We speculate and will test the idea that this pathway must be stimulated with the same pattern of stimulation that it shows after acute morphine injections that are rewarding.

Neural SC
The primitive neural stem cell initiates the building of the brain and then gives rise to the definitive neural stem cells that does most of the work of building the brain. Both of these rare neural stem cells persist into the adult brain and we are studying how to activate these relatively quiescent adult neural stem cells brain to regenerate lost neural tissue.
AI_Description: Two projects: 1) Studying opiate reward pathways in the ventral midbrain 2) Studying primitive and definitive neural stem cells that persist into adult brain
Student Roles: ROP students can expect to learn such skills as sterile techniques, biosafety level 1, and how to collect and analyze data. In many cases, students will also learn academic collaboration protocols, including how to work with their peers and with other labs. ROP students will also be asked to present their data at our weekly chalk talks and biweekly journal club meetings.
AI_Student Roles: ROP students will learn sterile techniques, biosafety level 1, data collection and analysis. Students will present at weekly chalk talks and biweekly journal club meetings.
Academic Outcomes: Both projects: Technical skills will include: autoclaving, microscopy, screening, preparing solutions and running behavioural assays, pipetting, DNA analysis, mouse breeding, and how to critically analyze data. The application of these skills will be relevant in all laboratory settings and especially important to understanding how to analyze, interpret and present data. This work will involve single cell RNA sequencing of the purified neural stem cell types, as well as methods to activate the adult neural stem cells in vivo. In our characterization of primitive and definitive neural stem cells from mouse brains, we employ cell culture and histological techniques that the ROP students will learn.
AI_Academic Outcomes: Technical skills in autoclaving, microscopy, screening, behavioral assays, pipetting, DNA analysis, mouse breeding, and data analysis.
Training & Mentorship: Students will be supervised by Dr. van der Kooy and an experienced laboratory technician.
AI_Training & Mentorship: Students will be supervised by Dr. van der Kooy and an experienced laboratory technician.

In the second step the final candidates are selected out of the interviewed candidates and offered a ROP position in the lab. Final selection criteria will include enthusiasm for research (the neurobiology of motivation and neural stem cells in particular), friendly personality that will match with others in the lab, and good marks.

Title: Game Design for Forensic Science Education
Description: The project for this course is the creation of an educational video game that teaches forensic science skills (collecting evidence, analysing the evidence in a lab, making statements about the analysis in court). This game is meant to be a virtual equivalent of a real-world assessment in forensic science courses, where students are presented with a scenario in a house that has been staged to resemble a crime scene. The game will model several of these crime scene scenarios, as well as the subsequent analysis and evidence presentation stages that follow.
AI_Description: Creating an educational video game teaching forensic science skills including evidence collection, lab analysis, and court presentation.
Student Roles: Students who take part in this project would be responsible for creating a single scenario in this virtual crime scene simulation. This would involve speaking with Forensic Science faculty and TAs to learn how the crime scene is staged, what actions the forensic students would perform and what assessment criteria are used in evaluating their performance. The student would use the ren'py framework to model the evidence collection, lab analysis and courtroom presentation for this scenario. This will require the students to storyboard the scene, create playable prototypes and incorporate feedback from faculty and players to arrive at a polished final product.
AI_Student Roles: Students will create scenarios in virtual crime scene simulation, working with Forensic Science faculty to model evidence collection, lab analysis, and courtroom presentation.
Academic Outcomes: Student enrolled in this course will get an introduction to basic game and user interface design. They will also learn about client interactions as they elicit requirements and incorporate feedback from a non-technical audience. The students will also have an opportunity to learn about forensic analysis and the key considerations when preparing assessments.
AI_Academic Outcomes: Introduction to game design, user interface design, client interactions, and understanding of forensic analysis and assessment preparation.
Training & Mentorship: Students in this ROP will be given weekly instruction on game design, user interfaces and user experience. They will learn about forensic analysis from the forensics faculty who are co-supervising the project. Students will need to have taken introductory programming courses before applying for this project, but our student mentors will provide guidance the ren'py framework (https://www.renpy.org/) and the creation of the game scenarios.
AI_Training & Mentorship: Weekly instruction on game design, UI/UX, guidance from student mentors on ren'py framework.
Selection Criteria: Students must be proficient in computer science, with at least an A grade in their university-level computer science courses. Past experience in designing user interfaces, video games or other interactive experiences is preferred but not required. Please mention any other experience that might be relevant to this project, outside of your computer science courses.

Title: Systems with Quantum Electronic Behaviour Nanoengineered from the bottom-up
Description: A theme of the Dhirani group's research is to use nanostructures as building blocks to fabricate quantum systems and to study their behaviour. This approach for fabricating systems is possible because of advances in the discovery and synthesis of a wide variety of nanostructures that can be used as building blocks. Also, there is a strong link between structure-behaviour at the nanoscale. Eg. "quantum dots" exhibit size-dependent optical and quantum effects; their discovery and development garnered a 2023 Nobel prize. We are particularly interested in "engineering" desired system behaviour from the bottom up. For example, this could enable us to shed light on previously observed but not well understood quantum phenomena even observe new phenomena. We also develop their potential device applications such as quantum electrochemistry, a field the Dhirani group is pioneering, and nanostructured direct solar-to-hydrogen energy conversion devices.
AI_Description: Research on using nanostructures as building blocks to fabricate quantum systems and study their behaviour, with applications in quantum electrochemistry and solar energy conversion.

Title: Simulating Complexity Chaos and Emergence
Description: We will build upon the research and model development completed by students between 2014 and 2024 in 3 areas. In the 1st area, we will explore the economic basis of social exclusion using insights from club theory and the Prisoners' Dilemma to test the emergence of scenarios, which produce a different outcome. The 2nd question looks at the long-term stability of urban form, a form that has been reproduces since humans started building settlements. We explore the resilience of this form by introducing errors into the simulation of its emergence. In the 3rd area, we will work use COBWEB to answer what-if questions about different designs for a vertical ecosystem. Using existing models means less time will be spent on model development and more time using the models to answer questions.
AI_Description: Research in economic basis of social exclusion, urban form stability, and vertical ecosystem design using COBWEB simulation.
Student Roles: As with previous ROPs, students will spend some time on identifying and reviewing the relevant literature in their area of research, writing an annotated bibliography and a literature review. Students will use systems diagrams and the literature review to refine their research question, existing gaps in the COBWEB model and modifications that are necessary to pursue our research question. Students are expected to work in a team to conduct this research, but some work will done individually. Students are expected to monitor communication from the Faculty Supervisor, respond to questions in a timely manner, attend the weekly lab meetings and contribute to the Lab environment through their professional and supportive interactions with regular attendees and visitors.
AI_Student Roles: Literature review, systems diagrams, model refinement, teamwork, and participation in weekly lab meetings.
Academic Outcomes: Students in this ROP will experience a research environment that will offer opportunities for growth through mentoring, teamwork and leadership. They will learn how to communicate their understanding of ideas, to develop critical thinking and connect ideas through writing a literature review, developing a systems diagram, and writing the final report. Visual communication and teamwork skills will be developed through working with others on a poster and a PowerPoint presentation. Students will learn the basics of experimental design and develop analytical thinking skills as they set up and draw conclusions from experiments. Students who would like to experience model development will be allowed to do so individually or through leading a team of high school students.

Because our primary tool, COBWEB, can simulate the outcomes of multiple populations, students will be trained on the basics of hypothesis testing using parametric and non-parametric statistics, and experimental design. Title: Perception of scenes in the real world and the visual arts
Description: Consider for a moment the range of images that one might categorize as a picture of a forest. These images may have a wide variety of characteristics, many of which could overlap with other categories of images (e.g. beaches or mountains). However, when we see a forest, we can immediately categorize it without the need to first recognize individual trees and then infer the forest. Humans are remarkably adept at this seemingly difficult perceptual categorization process, and for good reason --recognizing the essence of a scene (often called "scene gist"), provides important context for subsequent more detailed analysis of our visual environment. In our lab we are exploring the computational, cognitive and neural mechanisms of natural scene perception.
AI_Description: Exploring computational, cognitive and neural mechanisms of natural scene perception.
Student Roles:
We are looking for motivated and reliable students who are interested in computation as applied to cognition and perception. Depending on their interests and prior experience, students will have the opportunity to be involved in:
1. Programming new experiments for behavioral testing, eye tracking, fMRI or MEG,
2. Computational analysis of images,
3. Computational manipulation of images that are to be tested in behavioral experiments,
4. Aiding with conducting behavioral or neuroimaging experiments (fMRI, MEG),
5. Computational analysis of data, including fMRI, MEG and eye tracking data,
6. Writing research reports and preparing data for publication.
AI_Student Roles: Programming experiments, computational analysis of images, conducting experiments, data analysis, writing research reports.
Academic Outcomes: In our lab we are exploring the computational, cognitive and neural mechanisms of natural scene perception. This project in particular explores computational aspects of natural scene perception, such as spatial frequency analysis of scenes, algorithmic analysis of line strokes by artists, or programming of new experimental paradigms in Matlab and Psychophyisics toolbox. This projects exists at the intersection of computer science, engineering, psychology, and cognitive neuroscience.
AI_Academic Outcomes: Experience with various software and hardware relevant for research, preparation for future research projects and graduate school.
Training & Mentorship: All students are expected to participate in and contribute to weekly lab meetings. For all aspects of the project, students will work closely with senior lab members (faculty supervisor, postdoc, graduate students). They will gain detailed experience with a variety of software (Matlab, Python, Photoshop, Illustator, R, Afni, Freesurfer) and hardware (eye tracker, psychophyisics setups) that is relevant for this research. The skills gained by working on this project will provide important experience to help prepare both for future research projects (e.g., thesis) and for graduate school.
AI_Training & Mentorship: Close work with senior lab members, training in software and hardware use, regular lab meetings.
Selection Criteria: Selection will proceed in two rounds. The first round will be based on academic background (grades, suitability of prior training) as well as the statement of research interests. Title: LDL transcytosis by coronary endothelial cells and the initiation of atherosclerosis

Title: Development and application of innovative radiopharmaceuticals for the diagnosis and assessment of treatment in neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative disorders
Description:
Positron emission tomography (PET) is a cutting-edge molecular imaging technique that enables the noninvasive visualization, characterization, and quantification of biological processes at cellular and molecular levels. This course will include the applications of PET imaging in central nervous system (CNS) disorders, particularly focusing on Alzheimer's disease, multiple sclerosis, and neuropsychiatric disorders. The primary objectives of this course are twofold:
1. Discovery of Cutting-edge Radiopharmaceuticals for Brain Imaging Applications: Students will explore the development and optimization of radiolabeled molecular probes specifically designed for brain imaging. They will learn about the synthesis and characterization of these radiopharmaceuticals and their potential applications in diagnosing and monitoring brain disorders.
2. Developing and Applying Novel PET Imaging Methods: Students will learn the design and implementation of innovative PET imaging methods that directly capture biochemical or phenotypic changes in vivo related to brain disorders, specifically for Alzheimer's disease and multiple sclerosis.

Course Topics Include:
1. New Brain Imaging Biomarkers for Brain Disorders: Students will study the latest advancements in brain imaging biomarkers, focusing on their relevance to various neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders. They will analyze research findings to understand the role of imaging biomarkers in disease diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment monitoring.
2. PET Imaging in Alzheimer's Disease Drug Discovery: Students will explore the use of PET imaging techniques in drug discovery and development for Alzheimer's disease. Topics covered will include amyloid imaging, tau imaging, and other PET biomarkers relevant to Alzheimer's pathology. Students will learn about the challenges and opportunities in developing novel therapeutics for Alzheimer's based on PET imaging insights.
3. PET Imaging in Multiple Sclerosis Drug Discovery: This segment of the course will focus on the application of PET imaging in multiple sclerosis research and drug discovery. Students will examine imaging biomarkers for assessing disease activity, neuroinflammation, and treatment response in multiple sclerosis patients. Discussions will also encompass the integration of PET imaging data with other clinical and laboratory measures in multiple sclerosis research.
4. PET Imaging in Neuropsychiatric Disorders Drug Discovery: Students will explore the role of PET imaging in studying neuropsychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia, depression, and anxiety disorders. They will examine imaging biomarkers related to neurotransmitter systems, neuroinflammation, and synaptic function in these disorders. Discussions will revolve around using PET imaging data to inform drug discovery strategies and personalized treatment approaches in neuropsychiatry.

Throughout the course, students will engage in interactive lectures, hands-on experiments on radiopharmaceuticals and small animal PET imaging, and preclinic research projects. They will gain practical experience in radiochemistry, quantitative PET imaging analysis, and the interpretation of imaging data in drug discovery and development. By the end of the course, students will have a comprehensive understanding of PET imaging applications in brain disorders and be equipped with valuable skills for pursuing careers in molecular imaging research and drug development.

Title: Optimal filtering of spatial modes of light
Description: A common challenge in laser physics is mode cleaning: increasing the coherence of a beam of light by suppressing or eliminating higher-order modes. An ideal mode filter would transmit 100% of the desired mode, and completely block all remaining modes. In the spatial domain, such an ideal filter exists: a single-mode fiber (SMF). When one cannot use an SMF for technical reasons (such as high laser power) or fundamental reasons (filtering higher-order spatial modes), an alternative approach for mode cleaning is to use a "spatial filter" consisting of a series of apertures interleaved with lenses and other optical elements. Here, we study to what extent one can achieve ideal filtering performance for an arbitrary spatial mode.
AI_Description: A common challenge in laser physics is mode cleaning: increasing the coherence of a beam of light by suppressing or eliminating higher-order modes.
Student Roles: In this project, the student will simulate a generalized version of the spatial filter, consisting of lenses (which act to guide and confine the light), and masks or apertures (used to block undesirable parts of the optical mode). The student will optimize the filter's performance by varying the positions and shapes of the constituent lenses and masks to maximize the transmission of the mode of interest while suppressing all others, aiming to approach the ideal performance of an SMF for arbitrary spatial modes. The student will verify the properties of the spatial filter they designed by validating its performance experimentally.
AI_Student Roles: In this project, the student will simulate a generalized version of the spatial filter.
Academic Outcomes: In this course, the student will develop their understanding of spatial modes of light and optical systems, build skills in numerical modeling, and learn about experimental techniques of lasers and optics. Title: Molecular dialogue between plants and fungi
Description: Plants and fungi have evolved a chemical 'language of life' to coordinate their exchange of nutrients. The overarching goal of my research program is to translate the small molecule dialogue between plants and other organisms to improve plant, soil, and human health. However, we do not understand how plants and fungi respond to these signals in the soil. Mostly, this is because fungi and crops are genetically intractable. By turning to model systems like yeast and Arabidopsis, we have developed a pipeline to identify targets and processes of plant signals.
AI_Description: Plants and fungi have evolved a chemical 'language of life' to coordinate their exchange of nutrients.
Student Roles:
Depending on our progress, the students could be involved in a variety of projects in the lab. In Project 1, the ROP students will isolate and characterize yeast mutants that have an altered response to plant signals using a set of reporters. They will perform genetic screens as well as growth and biochemical assays on either yeast or other fungi.

In Project 2, students will screen a mutagenized Arabidopsis population to isolate mutants defective in the synthesis of a novel secreted hormone. Students will propagate, harvest, and screen Arabidopsis populations for mutants. They will also identify candidate knockout lines that cannot make this hormone by extracting DNA, genotyping by PCR, and collecting plant exudates for biochemical analysis.
AI_Student Roles: Students will be involved in isolating and characterizing yeast mutants and screening mutagenized Arabidopsis populations.

In both projects, students will learn principles of genetic analysis and the logic of signalling pathways. They will acquire molecular, cell biology, and biochemistry skills. In Project 1, students will learn sterile microbiological techniques and how to perform large-scale genetic screens and growth assays using a plate reader and automated equipment. Students will image cells on high-resolution microscopes to characterize fluorescent patterns and morphological phenotypes.

In Project 2, students will learn how to extract DNA from plants, genotype by PCR, and collect plant exudates for biochemical analysis. Students will image plant cells on high-resolution microscopes to characterize fluorescent patterns and morphological phenotypes. They will also gain bioinformatic skills to analyse sequences of candidate genes in the synthesis of the novel plant hormone and use the AI-based platform AlphaFold to predict structures and functions of these proteins.

Title: Genetic analysis of synaptic transmission in C. elegans
Description: Synaptic transmission is essential for neuronal communication in the brain. At synapses, electrical activity in the presynaptic neuron triggers rapid release of neurotransmitters in a Ca2+-dependent manner. The neuronal SNARE complex, consisting of syntaxin-1, SNAP-25, and synaptobrevin/VAMP-2, plays a central role in mediating neurotransmitter release through membrane fusion/exocytosis. This process is regulated by key proteins such as Munc18-1, Munc13, complexin, synaptotagmin and Tomosyn. Young children with mutations in genes that regulate synaptic vesicle exocytosis can develop devastating phenotypes, which are presently without adequate therapies. For instance, mutations in syntaxin-1B, Munc18, Munc13 and Tomosyn underlie a wide spectrum of childhood epilepsy and autism spectrum disorders (ASDs). However, the precise regulatory mechanisms of exocytosis remain largely unclear. Importantly, molecular mechanisms controlling synaptic transmitter exocytosis are highly conserved from C. elegans to humans. Using C. elegans as our model system, we will investigate the mechanisms of transmitter release.
AI_Description: Synaptic transmission is essential for neuronal communication in the brain.
Student Roles: ROP students will be involved in genotyping, behavioral, pharmacological, and morphological assays.
AI_Student Roles: ROP students will be involved in genotyping, behavioral, pharmacological, and morphological assays.
Academic Outcomes:
We aim to understand how SNARE proteins and the regulatory proteins interact with each other to achieve precise regulation of synaptic exocytosis. To address this question, it is important to examine their genetic interactions by generating double, triple and quadruple mutants.

To understand the interrelationship among the regulatory proteins, students will learn how to cross or mate the respective mutant strain to generate double and triple mutants. The students will then genotype the crossed animals using genotype PCR. The students will also learn how to analyze the phenotypes of the resulting mutants using behavioral and pharmacological assays. Behavioral assays are made by video recording of swimming worms and counting the number of thrashing behaviors. The pharmacological assays measure the sensitivity to aldicarb, an inhibitor of acetylcholine esterase. Since acetylcholine is the transmitter that is released from motor neurons to contract muscles, the sensitivity to aldicarb is proportional to the amount of released acetylcholine. In these processes, the students will learn the concept of genetic interactions among the regulatory proteins as well as behavioral and pharmacological assay techniques. The students will also learn how to modify the genome of C. elegans using CRISPR/Cas9 system and generate novel synaptic release mutants.

Title: Heterogeneity and the Immune Response in Breast Cancer
Description:
Through analysis of circulating tumour cells (CTCs) from breast cancer patients we have identified a distinctive 'CTC-signature' or pattern of genetic changes that can be found at low levels in primary breast cancers but at higher levels in CTCs and breast cancer metastases. This progression is associated with changes in genomic heterogeneity or variability within the tumor (H score).

We believe that this 'CTC-signature' are genetic alterations that are critical for metastasis. Also, that the degree of its variation within the cells of a breast cancer is important. We think that further development of this `CTC signature' will lead to a useful predictor of metastasis and provide targetable alterations that can be used to block breast cancer metastasis and reduce deaths. It is important for us to validate the CTC signature in a larger number of patients than we originally studied.

As we expect our signature to have prognostic value, we will compare it to a widely used clinical tool (Oncotype Dx assay) and measure it in more breast cancer metastases.

These experiments will help us gain a better understanding of how breast cancer spreads beyond the breast. Most breast cancer deaths are a result of spread beyond the breast so it is vital that we learn more about this process. A better understanding will lead to strategies to block metastasis.

Title: Revealing the Galaxy Formation and the Nature of Dark Matter with Galactic Archaeology
Description:
Four students enrolled in this course will work with Prof. Li and the two postdoctoral fellows (Nathan Sandford and Gustavo Medina) in her group, along with other graduate students. The course will contain two sub-projects, with 2 students for each sub-project. The students will work together and collaborate as a team.

Project 1: Searching for Stellar Streams with Large Scale Spectroscopic Survey Data
Our galaxy, the Milky Way, is surrounded by numerous small galaxies and star clusters that can be influenced by its gravitational forces, leading to the formation of stellar streams-celestial "rivers" orbiting around our galaxy. These streams offer a unique opportunity for astronomers to delve into the mysteries of galaxy formation and the elusive nature of dark matter. Cutting-edge cosmic surveys provide access to comprehensive data on millions of stars in our universe, including their full 6D information (position and velocity). The ROP student will be at the forefront of developing a Bayesian framework to assess the membership probability of each star in potential streams and to characterize the properties of these stellar streams. This involves leveraging vast astronomical datasets, totaling several gigabytes of data, obtained from one of the largest spectroscopic surveys, the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI, https://www.desi.lbl.gov/).
In this research project, the ROP student will explore the development and application of innovative statistical and computational techniques. These methodologies are crucial not only for unraveling the secrets hidden within stellar streams but also for paving the way for future astronomical surveys.

Project 2: The Chemodynamical Evolution of the Smallest Galaxies
The chemical composition and kinematics of stars provide a unique tracer of a galaxy's evolution over cosmic time. Supernovae, stellar winds, and neutron star mergers each leave a unique signature in the abundance patterns of stars observed today through which a diverse range of astrophysical processes can be studied. The stellar chemistry of dwarf galaxies around the Milky Way provides an especially powerful lens through which to study stellar and galactic physics, as their low-mass dark matter halos and ancient stellar populations make them sensitive to the physics of stellar feedback and star formation in the early Universe.
In this project, the ROP student will apply existing galactic chemical evolution and dynamical models to large stellar datasets of nearby dwarf galaxies collected by spectroscopic surveys. Depending on interest, the student can focus their investigation on the following topics: the Milky Way's accretion history of satellite galaxies, the nucleosynthesis of heavy elements, and the nature of star formation and stellar feedback.

Title: Regulation of brain neuropeptides by nutrients, chemicals, and hormones
Description:
My laboratory has focused on the study of the cell biology of specific neuropeptide-secreting neurons from the hypothalamus and has the expertise to perform detailed mechanistic analysis of cellular function. We have used the best available models of hypothalamic neurons, generated in my laboratory and used worldwide, to dissect and understand the molecular mechanisms utilized in the direct control of specific neuropeptides by peripheral signals, such as hormones, nutrients and neurotransmitters. We have previously found that exposure the saturated fatty acids causes neuroinflammation and endoplasmic reticulum stress in hypothalamic neurons. Thus we aim to alleviate these detrimental effects with anti-inflammatories and other therapeutic compounds.

We will use our well-characterized clonal hypothalamic cell lines (Endocrinology 145:393-400, 2004; FASEB J 23:4256-65, 2010) to study exactly what neuropeptides may be sensitive to nutrient or industrial chemical-mediated regulation and whether specific signal transduction pathways and transcriptional mechanisms are directly involved in the regulation of specific neuropeptides linked to feeding. We intend to follow-up on these studies by blocking these pathways with pharmacological inhibitors.
AI_Description: Study of cell biology of specific neuropeptide-secreting neurons from the hypothalamus, focusing on molecular mechanisms.
Student Roles: The ROP will be used towards the training of an undergraduate student in defining the molecular events in specific hypothalamic neurons known to be involved in the control of energy homeostasis. Using realtime RT-PCR and siRNA technologies, we will analyze whether specific transcription factors or microRNAs are able to regulate neuropeptide gene expression (for example, neuropeptide Y, proopiomelanocortin, melanocortin-concentrating hormone, neurotensin). Further, western blot analysis with phospho-specific antibodies towards individual signaling components will be used to assess changes in signal transduction.
AI_Student Roles: Training in molecular events in hypothalamic neurons, using RT-PCR and siRNA technologies, western blot analysis.
Academic Outcomes: These techniques are already established in my laboratory and will likely yield results over the term of the studentship. Many of my former undergraduate students have been included on lab publications, especially if they continue with the preliminary studies with another project or summer studentship.
AI_Academic Outcomes: Techniques are established in laboratory with potential for publication involvement.

AI_Training & Mentorship: Training in routine techniques, independent project assignment, daily supervision by senior trainee, weekly lab meetings.

Title: Simulating the Impact of Vegetation on the Urban Heat Island
Description: The urban heat island (UHI) is a phenomenon that emerges as vegetation is removed from urban areas, resulting in a warming effect that raises local temperatures by as much as 10 C. The UHI is of even more concern with the expected increase in extreme heatwaves, which are expected in a warmer climate. Warmer urban temperatures increase the energy demand for air conditioning, the frequency of severe pollution and heat-related health issues. Restoring vegetation or adding white surfaces to these areas are two strategies to reduce the urban heat island. We will build upon the research from the Urban Rewilding ROP that utilized the ENVIMet software to represent specific parts of a city, with and without vegetation/white walls at ground level, on the walls and on the roofs. We will be assessing how green roofs, walls and trees/shrubs affect the surface temperature on the building and on the temperature of the immediate area surrounding the building. Students will conduct research on a building surround by parking lot (i.e. a shopping mall), a building surround by a lawn (for example a school), bioswales/enhanced tree pits and other low-rise buildings. Preliminary work in the Urban Rewilding ROP has illustrated some interesting feedbacks when different surfaces are used in combination. These feedbacks will be explored further in this ROP. In particular, students will use ENVIMet to explore the feedback between white walls and temperatures in a parking lot. If sufficient information for any building is available, students will be able to use the results from ENVIMet in a building energy model.
AI_Description: Research on urban heat island effects and the impact of vegetation using ENVIMet software.
Student Roles: As with previous ROPs, students will spend some time on identifying and reviewing the relevant literature in their area of research, writing an annotated bibliography and a literature review. Title: Expression and purification of antibodies

Antibodies are large Y-shaped proteins produced by immune cells in response to antigens, or markers, that the body does not recognize. Title: Nonreciprocal Optical Cavities
Description:
In most optical systems, light that is time-reversed by reversing its propagation direction and phase will exactly retrace its path. This property, known as reciprocity, is very general and has far-reaching consequences in optics (for example, this principle prevents the realization of true "one-way mirrors"). In the context of optical ring cavities (where light circulates either in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction), reciprocity implies that the resonance frequency will generically be the same for light travelling in opposing directions.

In some applications, including laser cavities and gyroscopes, it would be desirable if these counter-propagating resonances had slightly different frequencies, which can only be achieved by adding a special "non-reciprocal" optical element into the cavity. The goal of this research project is to design these low-loss non-reciprocal optical elements, and test their performance in a laser power enhancement cavity.
AI_Description: Design and testing of low-loss non-reciprocal optical elements in laser power enhancement cavity.
Student Roles: In this project, the student will design and build low-loss, non-reciprocal optical elements based on the Faraday effect, which will involve designing and simulating a suitable magnet arrangement and a method to introduce a polarization-dependent refractive index using strain. The student will then test and characterize the performance of these elements when incorporated into an optical ring cavity.
AI_Student Roles: Design and build optical elements, test and characterize performance in optical ring cavity.
Academic Outcomes: In this course, the student will develop their understanding of optics and optical systems, build skills in numerical modeling, and gain experience in experimental techniques with lasers and optics. The student will also improve their written and oral communication skills for cutting-edge scientific topics.
AI_Academic Outcomes: Develop understanding of optics systems, numerical modeling skills, experimental techniques.

Description:
Fungi host diverse microbial communities, including bacteria that live as endosymbionts. These bacteria influence their host's metabolism, growth, and ecological interactions. However, many of these bacteria-fungi associations remain undiscovered, presenting an exciting opportunity to uncover novel biological relationships.

In the lab, we have observed bacteria that appear to reside in yeast. This project will employ advanced bioinformatics tools to identify bacterial communities within publicly available fungal genomic and metagenomic datasets. Students will develop computational pipelines to extract, classify, and analyze bacterial sequences, contributing to our understanding of microbial ecology and symbiosis.

The research questions are:
1. Which bacterial species are commonly associated with fungi?
2. How does bacterial diversity vary across fungal species or environments?
3. What functional roles do bacterial genes play in fungi?
To identify and characterize bacterial communities associated with fungi, students will apply bioinformatics approaches on real-world genomic and metagenomic datasets from fungal species of interest. Examples include S. cerevisiae, Aspergillus, and Rhizopus. The student will use online tools and learn computational approaches to obtain and analyse large sequence data.

The methodology is as follows:
1. Data Collection and Preparation
* Retrieve fungal genome and metagenome of sequence read archive (SRA) datasets from repositories like NCBI, JGI, and EMBL-EBI.
2. Bioinformatics Workflow
* Classify bacterial sequences using taxonomic tools.
* Assemble and bin genomes.
* Validate bacterial sequences.
3. Functional Annotation
* Annotate bacterial genes.
* Identify genes linked to nutrient exchange, secondary metabolite production, and symbiosis.
4. Data Analysis and Visualization
* Compare bacterial diversity across fungal species.
* Visualize bacteria-fungi relationships.

Furthermore, the student will construct phylogenetic trees to map bacterial diversity across the fungal kingdom. They will then generate evolutionary hypotheses about bacteria-fungi relationships.

Title: Building and Employing a Novel C. elegans Strain to Use in a Drug Development Pipeline
Description: Our lab is developing novel nematicides and insecticides for the treatment of parasites and vectors of disease. We are focused on developing compounds that are bioactivated by cytochrome P450s into lethal products that kill the targeted organism. From previous work, we have identified a number of small molecules that we suspect are bioactivated by the nematode C. elegans into lethal products. In this project, the student will develop a novel C. elegans strain to test the hypothesis that the nematicidal molecules within our collection do indeed kill C. elegans via cytochrome P450-mediated bioactivation.
AI_Description: Our lab is developing novel nematicides and insecticides for the treatment of parasites and vectors of disease. We are focused on developing compounds that are bioactivated by cytochrome P450s into lethal products that kill the targeted organism.
Student Roles: The ROP student will use CRISPR-based technology to create a degron allele of the C. elegans cytochrome P450 POR (P450-oxido-reductase) co-factor EMB-8. Without EMB-8, C. elegans' P450s cannot function. Of note, a degron allele will be a fusion between the coding sequence of an auxin-inducible degron (AID) tag and the coding seqeunce of EMB-8. Upon exposure to the auxin small molecule, the EMB-8::AID fusion protein will become ubiquitinated and degraded by the proteasome. With the C. elegans strain carrying the EMB-8 degron allele, the student will then test whether the suspected P450-bioactivated nematicides lose their lethality, which would support our hypothesis. The student will be responsible for using molecular biology to build the necessary DNA constructs, inject the nematodes with the constructs, create the required worm strain, and perform dose-response analyses to determine whether the candidate nematicides lose their lethality in worms with EMB-8 degraded.

Title: Neurocognitive development, socioemotional wellbeing, and learning
Department: Ontario Institute for Studies in Education
Description:

Project A Summary:
For refugee children, displacement and migration often correspond to a period of interrupted schooling and limited literacy instruction. As refugee children resettle in Canada, they resume learning to read at school. However, refugee children significantly lag behind their peers, both native English-speaking students as well as other newcomers to Canada and English language learners, in reading. While interrupted schooling clearly has a negative impact on literacy, little is known about the specific effects of interrupted schooling across the developmental trajectory for reading, and even less is known about the neurobiological mechanisms by which interrupted schooling impacts the neural systems that support reading. By leveraging the latest tools of educational neuroscience (functional neuroimaging tools, specifically functional Near Infrared Spectroscopy; fNIRS), this research examines the neural systems that support reading development for children who have experienced periods of interrupted schooling at different ages and who have resumed schooling, and learning to read, at an older age.

Title: Heritage Language speakers in Variationist Sociolinguistics
Description:
The Heritage Language Variation and Change Project (HLVC, http://ngn.artsci.utoronto.ca/HLVC) documents and describes heritage languages spoken by immigrants and two generations of their descendants in Toronto. Our primary goal is to define the types of linguistic variation and change, working with conversational speech data from 10 languages. We seek curious students who are fluent in one of the languages in the project.

Given that over half of the world's population is multilingual, it's strange that in variationist sociolinguistics, the trend has been to examine one language at a time, essentially treating speakers as monolingual. The HLVC project documents and describes heritage languages spoken by immigrants and two generations of their descendants in the Greater Toronto Area, contrasting grammars at various degrees of contact to homeland varieties and to English spoken in those communities.
  
Goals include:
* building a large corpus of Heritage Language data available to other researchers
* using a standardized framework to examine variation in different languages and at different levels of grammar (e.g., pronunciation, morphology, sentence-structure).
* defining the types of changes that do and do not occur in Heritage Languages more fully.

A major contribution of this project is a standardized method for quantitative linguistic analysis of variation within multilingual communities, allowing the field to expand beyond its monolingual core and focus on English. We are moving beyond our field's bias toward examining larger, dominant languages. The languages we examine (Cantonese, Faetar, Hungarian, Italian, Korean, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Tagalog, Ukrainian) have been strategically selected for available resources, contrasting inherent traits, and degrees of divergence from English.

We analyse cross-generational change in the forms of the languages used. Building on existing methods of determining whether different varieties share the same grammar, we will determine how similar two grammars are, showing how much each generation's variety has shifted from the original (homeland) variety. Title: Reading Comprehension among Majority and Minority Language Children in French Immersion
Department: Ontario Institute for Studies in Education
Description:
For children in French Immersion, success in school is dependent on the ability to read for understanding in French and English. Over the middle to upper elementary years, reading comprehension is increasingly influenced by language skills (vocabulary, morphology, syntax, listening comprehension). Our research program has four specific objectives:
1. to develop models formalizing the contribution of language skills to English and French reading comprehension in majority and minority language children between grades 3 and 6
2. to investigate the direction and degree of English and French cross-language transfer over time
3. to examine the effect of language status (children who speak English vs. a minority language as L1) on English and French language and literacy learning
4. to explore other factors that may contribute to reading comprehension in English and French, such as executive functions (e.g., attention, memory, inhibition, etc.).

Title: Brain circuitry supporting transitive inference
Description: Transitive inference enables us to predict a relationship between items that have never been presented together based on previous learning of a set of overlapping premises. Previous studies show that mice can correctly evaluate the unobserved relationship, as humans do. This opens up an opportunity to thoroughly investigate how this cognitive process is implemented in the brain by applying various biological research tools to mice. In this ROP project, we will monitor the expression of genes in brain cells in mice to identify which brain regions become activated during the transitive inference task.

Then, they will process the brain tissues to visualize the expression of an activity-regulated gene. The students will also use a microscope to take images of brain tissues and use them to quantify the number of activated brain cells in several brain regions. In parallel, the students will conduct a literature search on previous studies on transitive inference in humans and non-human animals. Please note that this project takes place in person on the St. George campus. We expect the students to participate in lab experiments for a minimum of three hours per day and five days a week.

Title: Computational and Operational Principles of an Intact Neural System
Description: C. elegans offers an ideal platform for studying how a nervous system develops and operates to generate complex behaviors. Title: Sodium leak channel NALCN's role in neural circuits and development
Description: Sodium leak current is a key player in neuronal activity modulating the resting membrane potential and firing frequency. The sodium leak channel NALCN is an essential channel conducting this current. Mutations of this channel caused severe intellectual disability, motor disability, developmental delay, cerebellar atrophy, and ataxia. While the crystalized structure and the basic biophysical properties have been identified, the role of this channel in circuit level and development is still largely unclear. We will explore the answer by examining and comparing the neuronal activity, development, connectivity, and behavior in wild-type, conditional NALCN gain and loss-of-function mice.

Title: How does creativity develop?
Description: Past work has revealed developmental differences in creativity at both the neural and behavioural levels, but it is unclear how these differences relate to the development of processes like memory and learning. In this project, we are examining developmental change in the influence of episodic memory on different aspects of creativity, using functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) to capture the neural correlates of creative cognition in adults and children (6-10 years old) and to understand how prefrontal brain regions support creativity. The objective of this study is to understand the developmental interplay between memory, learning, and creativity, aiming to elucidate how cognitive processes supporting creativity evolve. We will ask these questions using a variety of behavioural and brain imaging methodologies. The primary methodology of this ROP project involves fNIRS neuroimaging while participants complete computer-based tasks, in which we will measure participants' accuracy, verbal responses, and response times to assess their creative abilities. Students will be thoroughly trained on how to collect data with the fNIRS system and how to implement our tasks before independently collecting adult and child data. In addition to collecting fNIRS data from adults and children, students will learn the theoretical background of creativity, its development, and its neural basis, as well as the technical aspects of processing, analyzing, and visualizing fNIRS data.

Title: Molecular modulation of reproductive success - from egg to placenta
Description: Oocytes are dramatically affected by aging, evidenced by their poor developmental competence, increase in aneuploidy, altered gene expression and decreased ATP production. We will also study the role of microRNAs in trophoblast function and development, since one of the roles of the placenta is to expose fetal cells to the maternal immune system.
AI_Description: Research examines how aging and genetic modifications affect oocyte development and trophoblast function in reproduction.

Title: Elucidating molecular structure by rotational spectroscopy and deep generative models
Description: The problem setting is structure elucidation: given an unknown chemical sample, what is its molecular structure? One approach is rotational spectroscopy, which measures the rotational constants of molecules in the gas-phase. Title: Computational Chemistry for Catalysis
Description:
Investigating the accuracy of computational chemistry methods in predicting reaction selectivity:
The selectivity of a chemical reaction shows the distribution of products generated by a reaction. Each mechanistic pathway that generates a product can be described by an overall energetic barrier, and the selectivity is determined by the relative ease of access between multiple mechanistic pathways. While these selectivities can be predicted using computational chemistry, due to the various approximations used by such methods to make them possible to calculate in a reasonable time, there are large deviations between predictions and experimental realities. However, density functional theory (DFT) calculations, one of the workhorse methods for computational organic chemistry, achieves good accuracies in the prediction of relative properties due to "error cancellation", where the systematic errors in these calculations cancel out. However, selectivities are the result of comparing two relative results. The common belief in the community is that error cancellation also carries over in such cases, but this is not well-established. The goal of this project is to determine if error cancellation occurs in the prediction of selectivities.

The impact of the boronic reagent on palladium-catalyzed protodeboronation:
Protodeboronation is a significant side reaction that causes the decomposition of the key boronic reagent in palladium-catalyzed Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling, the second most used catalytic reaction in medicinal chemistry. Recent work has shown that bulky ligands, used to promote the cross-coupling reaction, can also cause significant protodeboronation. However, the structural and electronic natures of the boronic reagent also plays a key role in the degree of protodeboronation. While the base-catalysis of electron-deficient or sterically hindered boronic reagents have been investigated in detail, this is not well understood for palladium-catalyzed protodeboronation. This project aims to investigate in detail how the boronic reagent affects palladium-catalyzed protodeboronation.
AI_Description: Investigating the accuracy of computational chemistry methods in predicting reaction selectivity and studying palladium-catalyzed protodeboronation.

Title: Efficient Full CI representation of Coupled Cluster wavefunctions
Description:
The Coupled Cluster (CC) method is renowned for its accuracy in approximating the ground state energy of molecular systems. While it is computationally more feasible than the exact Full Configuration Interaction (FCI) method, assessing its accuracy remains a significant challenge.
This project focuses on developing a cutting-edge tool to efficiently represent CC wavefunctions in a form that enables two key types of accuracy assessments:
      1. Direct comparison with the FCI wavefunction, providing a benchmark for CC solutions.
      2. Intrinsic evaluation via energy variance, offering a powerful way to gauge the reliability of CC calculations without needing exact solutions.
By exploring these accuracy metrics, the project aims to establish uncertainty indices that inform the reliability of CC methods, paving the way for better decision-making in computational chemistry.

Title: Theoretical and data science approaches for understanding the flexibility of metal-organic frameworks
Description:
Abstracts:
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are flexible porous materials. Pore shapes of MOFs can be changed by pressure, temperature, and guest molecules. Contrary to rigid porous materials (e.g. zeolite), MOFs can undergo pore shape changes during gas adsorption isotherms. Such flexibility leads to decreased working capacity in MOFs' gas storage applications. The flexible properties of MOFs are affected by the components and structure of MOFs such as metal, linkers, and topologies. Thus, understanding the MOF structures and flexibility is highly important in designing high-performing MOFs. However, the relationship between the MOF structures and flexibility has not been clearly studied.

In this project, the students will learn and perform density functional theory (DFT) calculations to obtain the reaction energy for breathing motion in MOFs, one of the most common motions during the gas storage process. Based on the reaction energy, we could predict the flexibility of MOFs. The students will use supercomputers (Compute Canada) or group clusters and learn how computational simulations are applied to real-world chemical research. Then, we build a database consisting of the reaction energies, features of MOFs (e.g. pore size, void volume), and components (e.g. metal and linkers used in the MOFs). By training machine learning models using the database, we could predict flexibility, systematically understand the relationship, and suggest how to design MOFs with minimized flexibility. Throughout this process, the students will acquire a comprehensive understanding of computer simulations and AI for chemistry workflow, including DFT calculations, supercomputing, chemical features, data collection, developing ML models, and other essential steps.

         * Collect structural features of MOFs: Zeo++

Title: Machine Learning methods for Molecular Aggregate Structure Prediction and Optical Property Correlation
Description:
Motivation: Molecular aggregates are formed through the assembly of individual molecules and exhibit distinct electronic and optical properties compared to their single-molecule counterparts. These properties arise from intermolecular interactions such as excitonic coupling, leading to J-aggregates (red-shifted absorption/emission) or H-aggregates (blue-shifted absorption/emission). Understanding and predicting these aggregate states is critical for advancing applications in organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), light-harvesting for solar cells, photonics, and biosensing.

Predicting the aggregate states and properties of organic molecules is a highly complex task due to the intricate interplay of molecular interactions, structural geometry, and environmental factors. Traditional computational methods, such as molecular dynamics and quantum chemistry simulations, require significant computational resources to model the vast configurational space of possible aggregate structures, including different packing geometries and intermolecular forces. Moreover, the influence of external factors, such as solvent interactions, temperature, and substrate effects, adds another layer of complexity that hinders the rational design of molecular materials with tailored aggregate properties. On the other hand, experimental characterization of aggregates is resource-intensive and time-consuming as it often requires a combination of linear and non-linear spectroscopic techniques such as linear absorption, fluorescence, time-resolved photoluminescence, and transient absorption spectroscopies.

Machine learning offers a powerful alternative by leveraging data-driven approaches to identify patterns and correlations that traditional methods fail to efficiently resolve, enabling rapid and accurate predictions of aggregation behavior and properties.

Objectives: This project aims at predicting molecular aggregation and aggregate properties of organic molecules by:
         * Creating a database linking single-molecule descriptors to aggregate states, including aggregate types (J- or H-aggregates), geometrical descriptors of aggregation, optical properties (absorption/emission frequencies, linewidths, and cross-section).
         * Developing machine learning (ML) models to predict aggregate states directly from single-molecule descriptors, such as SMILES (Simplified Molecular Input Line Entry System), representations embedded using graph neural networks (GNNs), Correlate aggregate descriptors with optical properties, enabling property-driven design of molecular aggregates, and validating the predictive models against experimental and computational datasets to ensure accuracy and generalizability.
Methodology:
         * Data Collection: a) Curate datasets of experimentally and computationally characterized aggregates. b) extract single-molecule descriptors (e.g., SMILES strings) and corresponding aggregate information (e.g., packing motifs, excitonic couplings and coherence lengths).
         * Machine Learning Framework: a) Train supervised ML models, such as GNNs, to predict aggregate states (e.g., J- or H-aggregates) from single-molecule features. b) Train secondary models to correlate aggregate descriptors with optical properties.
         * Validation and Benchmarking: a) Compare model predictions with known experimental data. b) Use molecular dynamics and quantum mechanical simulations to validate aggregate predictions for new molecules.

Title: Building a Theoretical Foundation for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning

Do you thrive on using theoretical approaches grounded in mathematical modeling and analysis to gain deeper insights into critical research questions and design efficient, scalable algorithms? Our research group is dedicated to building a theoretical foundation for multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) systems. MARL is a key subfield of machine learning, where multiple agents learn to interact within an environment to achieve specific goals. However, MARL presents several critical challenges, including imperfect state information, noisy and delayed reward signals, scalability issues, and the inability to directly observe other agents' actions.

Title: Song and Story. English Garlands and Songsters of the Eighteenth Century
Description: "Song and Story" investigates the publication and, where possible, reception of popular songbooks in eighteenth-century England. It has the objectives of ascertaining the subject-matter, themes, tunes and meanings of popular songs. This will be undertaken by collecting bibliographic data about eighteenth-century songbooks from the English Short Title Catalogue. This is an online bibliography of all English-language publications between 1450 and 1800 . That data will be filed in an Excel database by date, publisher, subject matter, themes, tunes, &. Content notes will also be taken on select material from Gale Cengage's Eighteenth-Century Collections Online: a vast library of primary source scanned publications to be accessed through the Robarts server. The notes will be filed in Zotero. Title: Automating knowledge graph construction using large language models
Description:
Research Question: How can we use large language models (LLMs) to automate the creation of knowledge graphs and improve their accuracy with input from students?

Objectives:
* Develop a workflow that uses LLMs to create a knowledge graph for a robotic arm based on its action logs.
* Test whether adding human knowledge as input improves the quality of the generated knowledge graph.

Methodology: A knowledge graph is a way of organizing and representing information, showing concepts and their relationships in a clear and structured way. Typically, creating these graphs requires advanced technical tools and deep expertise, which can be time-consuming and challenging. LLMs, such as ChatGPT, are powerful tools that can generate text, write code, and handle large amounts of information. This project will use LLMs to analyse logs of a robotic arm's actions and automatically extract information to build a knowledge graph. Students will also explore how adding human input as prior knowledge affects the results, comparing graphs generated with and without this input.

Student Engagement: Students will actively participate in all stages of the project, including:
            * Learning about knowledge graphs and how they can be used in technology.
            * Experimenting with LLMs to extract information from robotic arm action logs.
            * Testing and refining the workflow by adding their own insights to guide the LLMs.
            * Comparing the results and documenting the effectiveness of the method.

This project is an excellent opportunity for students to gain hands-on experience with cutting-edge AI tools and understand how knowledge representation can support real-world applications

Title: Understanding the Formation and Structure of Communities in Social Networks
Description:
Are you fascinated by the intricate ways in which people come together to form communities? This project offers a unique opportunity to delve into the intersection of computer science and sociology to uncover the mysteries behind social networks. The project is dedicated to answering one of the most intriguing questions in these fields: why and how do communities form in social networks? Using a unique mathematical model developed by our research team, we employ a computational approach to analyze the processes that drive community formation and the structures that emerge as a result.

The research aims to understand the fundamental principles and mechanisms that lead to the emergence of communities within social networks. By examining various types of community structures and how they differ based on different network conditions, we seek to uncover patterns and insights that have broad applications in both theoretical and practical contexts. Through the development and testing of advanced algorithms, we simulate and study community formation, evaluating their effectiveness through rigorous computational experiments.
AI_Description: This project investigates community formation in social networks using a mathematical model, computational simulations, and algorithm design. It focuses on exploring sociological theories, refining mathematical models, developing simulation algorithms, and performing data analysis.
Student Roles:
Students contribute to the investigation of community formation in social networks through computational modeling and algorithmic analysis. Responsibilities include:
Literature Review: Review existing research on community detection, network structures, and social dynamics. Identify gaps in current approaches and explore how our mathematical model can address these challenges.
Mathematical Modeling: Work with the project's mathematical framework to refine models of community formation. This may involve formalizing assumptions, proving theoretical properties, or adapting models to better capture real-world social network behavior.
Algorithm Development & Implementation: Design and implement algorithms that simulate and analyze network structures. Students will write efficient code in Python, test algorithmic performance, and optimize computational efficiency.
Computational Experiments: Develop experiments to test hypotheses on community formation, adjust simulation parameters, and analyze the results. Compare different algorithms and assess their effectiveness in various network conditions.
Data Analysis & Visualization: Interpret experimental results using statistical techniques and visualization tools. Create meaningful representations of network structures and community patterns.
Writing & Presentation: Document research findings in technical reports and presentations. Students will present their work in group meetings and contribute to research papers for potential publication.
This research enhances students' skills in mathematical modeling, programming, and computational social science.
AI_Student Roles: Students will conduct literature reviews, refine mathematical models, design and implement simulation algorithms, perform computational experiments, analyze network data, and document their findings.
Academic Outcomes:
By the end of the course, you will:
            * Develop an understanding of core sociological theories related to social actions, norms, and structures, and examine how these concepts can inform the formation and structure of communities in social networks.
            * Gain a solid foundation in the theoretical underpinnings of the formation and structure of communities.
            * Acquire knowledge of specific models and algorithms, along with an understanding of their properties and performance, including those for social network formation, social influence, and the emergence of social norms.
            * Build proficiency in applying social learning algorithms, emphasizing coordination and adaptive behaviors.
AI_Academic Outcomes: Students will acquire a deep understanding of sociological concepts, mathematical modeling techniques, algorithm development, and data analysis methods related to community formation in social networks.
Training & Mentorship:
Students will receive weekly one-on-one mentorship to discuss progress and refine research goals. Meetings will include research presentations, peer feedback, and problem-solving discussions. To prepare, students will submit short weekly reports summarizing their work, challenges, and questions. Additional support will be available through discussions with graduate students and the research team.
This project offers hands-on experience in computational social science, mathematical modeling, and algorithm design while developing practical research skills.

Title: Understanding Migration and Belief Responses to Climate Change-Driven Flooding and Heatwaves
Description: The primary goal is to measure how people respond to climate-change-driven disasters (floods and heatwaves), both in terms of moving and in terms of updating their beliefs. These two responses are strongly connected, as people make decisions about whether and where to move based on their beliefs about what different locations hold for them in the future. The work involved in this project is to approach this question scientifically. First, to gather and harmonize as much data as possible about disasters, migration, and beliefs. Then, to analyze this data to try to find suggestive patterns about responses. Then, to form hypotheses about what causal relationships are generating these patterns. Then, to formalize these hypotheses in the form of formal, testable models. Then, to estimate the parameters of those models using the data: "bringing the model to the data." Finally, potentially after some rounds of model testing and reformulation, to use this model and its estimated parameters to make predictions about how people will respond to future disasters.
AI_Description: This project measures responses to climate-change-driven disasters, focusing on migration and belief updates. It involves data gathering, cleaning, harmonizing microdata and geospatial data, developing structural models, and predictive modelling.
Student Roles: Much of the work of the students in the first stage will be in gathering, cleaning, harmonizing, compiling, and analyzing microdata and geospatial data. They will use the Python packages Pandas and Geopandas and create data cleaning code files that are capable of replicating their results. In the second stage, students will work together with me on theorizing about the sources of the patterns in the data, formulating a model, and bringing the model to the data. Finally, time permitting, they will work on exploring the consequences of the estimated model and creating predictions about the responses to future disasters.
AI_Student Roles: Students will gather, clean, and analyze microdata and geospatial data using Python (Pandas and Geopandas). They will also participate in model formulation, parameter estimation, and exploring predictive modelling regarding migration and belief responses.
Academic Outcomes:
Students will gain experience in:
            * Data science tools for working with microdata
            * Data science tools for working with geospatial data
            * Data science concepts relating to data cleaning and harmonization
            * Econometric data analysis and the application of economic reasoning to empirical patterns
            * Quantitative structural modelling
            * Hypothesis generation and testing with a structural perspective
            * Theories of migration and belief formation
            * Predictive modelling and theoretical concerns such as external valididty
AI_Academic Outcomes: Students gain experience with data science tools, econometric analysis, quantitative structural modelling, and theories of migration and belief formation, along with skills in hypothesis testing and predictive modelling.

Title: Deontic concepts in Sanskrit philosophy
Description: Like other deontic-related terms, the concept of "right" is not at all univocal in Euro-American common parlance and not even in legal philosophy. Within this project, we will reconsider the concept of rights by comparing and contrasting it with cognate concepts within Sanskrit philosophy and legal thought, focusing especially on the term adhik?ra, variously translated as 'entitlement' or 'responsibility'. The main source will be the most relevant Sanskrit legal text, the M?navadharma??stra (also known as Manusm?ti or "The Laws of Manu"), together with its learned commentary by Medh?tithi (9th c. CE). We will analyse what adhik?ra entailed and how it interacted with other deontic terms, such as obligation, prohibition and permission.

Title: Digital Humanities: From Paper to Online Database
Description:
Digital technology is profoundly transforming the Humanities. This project introduces students to manual and AI-assisted paleography (the deciphering of old hand(writing)s), archival research, the process of digitizing an archive and the history of Early Modern colonization by the Society of Jesus, a christian order which is at the time the single most important source of information on Non-European cultures.

The documents to be transcribed are mostly Latin documents dating from the 16th-18th century from the archive of the Jesuit order in Rome, ARSI (Archivum Romanum Socieatis Iesu). One series of documents are letters linked to the missions in New France. To get permission to leave for foreign lands, Jesuit missionaries needed to petition their superior. These letters, so called "letterÃ¦ indipetÃ¦" (https://indipetae.bc.edu/) are the object of the first digital enterprise of ARSI in collaboration with a group of international researchers and the Toronto Jesuit History Research Group (TJHRG) runs this ROP project in collaboration with Boston College.

Among the clusters of documents there is also one related to the Jesuit missions in "Huronia", the region inhabited by the Huron- Wendat people North of the GTA. These documents offer a first hand testimony of the interaction between the indigenous people of Canada and "Newcomers", providing historical depth to current debates around Truth and Reconciliation.
AI_Description: This project explores how digital technology transforms the Humanities. Students gain hands-on experience with manual and AI-assisted paleography, archival research, digitization, OCR and translation software, and metadata analysis related to Jesuit missions.
Student Roles: Students learn about the organization of an archive, the process of digitization and the preparation of the documents for online use. They will learn about Finder Helpers, classification of documents, the production of digital images and their transcription using manual labor, AI, OCR and translation software. They will learn to research metadata which requires background research on the authors of the letters and the circumstances of their writing. They will go through all the different editorial stages of a document until its electronic publication. The goal is to build up an open access electronic database by providing transcribed documents with their metadata. Students will be given credit for their transcriptions by their names at the moment of publication in the online database.
AI_Student Roles: Students learn about archive organization, document transcription through manual and AI methods, metadata research, and the editorial process to build an open-access online database.
Academic Outcomes:
Students will learn to handle digital material, to read "olds hands" (paleography) and develop computer skills (AI driven OCR-technology like Transkribus, chatgpt, DeepL, etc.). Students will participate in the various editorial stages and not only gain insights into historical and archival methods and the digital data management of the future, but also become part of the knowledge production process : they are credited for their work in the database.
Students will also learn about Western globalization, intercultural contact and knowledge production in the Jesuit missions to New France and Asia. Students can broaden their knowledge of foreign languages (Latin, French, Italian, etc.) and hone their interpersonal skills through team work in a scholarly community and an international network of scholars. It will also be an opportunity to reflect on the limits and opportunities of AI technologies in academic research and Digital humanities.
AI_Academic Outcomes: Students will gain skills in digital data management, paleography, historical research, and collaborative digital humanities work, along with language and translation skills.
Training & Mentorship:
The faculty supervisors have a very interdisciplinary background (literature, history, history of science) which will give students insights in various fields and approaches.
A series of structured workshops will provide the basics of paleography and historical biographical research.
