Title: Stereotyping, Prejudice, and Discrimination
Description:
I am interested in stereotyping and prejudice, both from the perceiver's and the target's perspective. In my lab my students and I are pursuing several interrelated questions, including:
            1. How do combinations of identities (e.g., race and gender) influence perceiver's reactions?
            2. How do people respond to individuals with ambiguous identities (e.g., multiracial people, people with concealable stigmas)?
            3. How do stereotypes and prejudice affect stigmatized individuals?
            4. How can we reduce stereotyping and prejudice?
In my lab students will work on a variety of projects addressing the research questions listed above (e.g., How can we reduce stereotyping and prejudice?). We use a variety of methods to address our questions, including online surveys, choice reaction time tasks, and sometimes cognitive tasks (e.g., memory/recall tasks). We collect data from a variety of participant platforms both in the Psychology Department as well as online.

It examines how combinations of identities influence reactions, responses to ambiguous identities, and how stereotypes affect stigmatized individuals, with an aim to reduce prejudice.

Title: Synthesis of Nickel Oxide Superconductors using Extreme Thermodynamics
Description: This course will attempt to synthesize superconducting nickel oxides using extreme thermodynamics. Both powder and thin-film samples will be synthesized, in an effort to isolate chemical phases that show superconductivity but are metastable in bulk form under ambient temperatures and pressures. Title: APLUS for University Students' Communication Skill Development
Department: Ontario Institute for Studies in Education
Description:
The primary goal is to examine the impact of APLUS on support for incoming undergraduate U of T students' academic oral and written language development through self-guided and automated feedback support. The integration of APLUS into summer onboarding programs or through embedding APLUS into current curriculums will play a role in incoming students' transition into university studies by supporting student success and academic excellence, all the while facilitating a smoother transition to university life. The APLUS learning-oriented assessment platform was developed for instructors and students to assess and monitor students' academic communication skills using integrative tasks via the ISEF grant in 2020. As the automated machine scoring algorithms have become active after extensive validation based on human scores, the APLUS platform is ready to be widely adopted to significantly impact student support at the University of Toronto. We examine the relationship between oral and written communication ability and the role of self-concepts on students' communication skills. We further investigate valid ways to automate the data processing and scoring process for immediate feedback. We pay close attention to potential biases associated with students' accents and backgrounds in data scoring process using AI.

Title: Mounds & Memory around the Great Lakes
Description:
This ROP gives motivated and self-directed students the chance to join a research team focused on community-engaged research in the Anishinaabe territory of Grand Council Treaty #3 (northwestern Ontario). The main project, "Mounds & Memory", focuses on mounds and earthworks, monumental human-made landforms which have served for thousands of years as ceremonial gathering spaces, burial sites, astronomical landmarks, pilgrimage destinations, and centers of Indigenous politics, mobility, and commerce. Working in collaboration with Indigenous and settler public history organizations in the Great Lakes region, the Mounds and Memory project catalogues settler narratives of the mound builders and examines how they continue to have an effect on the mounds themselves. The project also documents and analyzes how Indigenous peoples have written and performed counter-narratives that center mounds as material witnesses of their ongoing relationship with the land, which they continue to visit and steward as places of ceremony. A second developing project focuses on helping to gather resources and transmit community histories related to Powwows in the area.

Title: Measuring and Boosting the Productivity of Disabled Workers: The Case of Food-Delivery Workers
Description:
This course offers students the opportunity to actively participate in a meaningful research project that investigates how to improve the productivity and work experiences of disabled workers, specifically hearing-impaired food-delivery drivers on a major Chinese platform. The research addresses critical questions: How do disabled workers perform compared to non-disabled workers? What challenges do they face? How can new technologies or workplace policies help improve their performance and inclusion?

The project aims to fill a significant research gap by providing one of the first detailed analyses of productivity differences between disabled and non-disabled workers in the gig economy. The findings will offer valuable insights for platforms, policymakers, and researchers to develop strategies that promote workplace inclusion and productivity for disabled workers.

This ROP course has three key objectives:
1. Understanding Productivity Patterns: Using a dataset covering over 60,000 workers, including 10,641 with disabilities, students will analyze weekly worker performance metrics, such as the number of completed orders, customer ratings, and delivery times. The analysis will also examine how disabled workers perform under different conditions, like extreme weather or peak hours.
2. Identifying Challenges and Bottlenecks: Students will engage in ethnographic fieldwork and interviews with hearing-impaired workers to uncover the specific obstacles they face in their daily work. This qualitative approach complements the data analysis, providing deeper insights into the barriers to productivity.
3. Evaluating Interventions: The study focuses on a real-time transcription tool introduced on the platform. This tool converts spoken language into text, enabling better communication between hearing-impaired workers, customers, and restaurants. Students will help assess its effectiveness using statistical techniques like difference-in-differences analysis.

Students enrolled in this course will gain hands-on experience in all stages of the research process:
1. Data Analysis: Students will work with the rich administrative dataset, learning to clean and organize data, calculate productivity metrics, and perform advanced statistical analyses using software such as Stata, R, or Python.
2. Fieldwork and Interviews: Students will assist in developing interview questions, conducting interviews with disabled workers, and transcribing the recordings. They will also have the opportunity to observe workers in the field, gaining firsthand insights into their experiences.
3. Evaluating Results: Students will analyze the impact of the transcription tool and help identify mechanisms that improve productivity. They will also contribute to documenting findings for policy recommendations and academic presentations.
4. Skill Development: Throughout the course, students will build valuable skills in quantitative data analysis, qualitative research, and academic writing. They will also gain experience in working within a diverse, inclusive research team, with training on equity, diversity, and inclusion principles.

This project's findings have the potential to influence workplace policies and technologies that support disabled workers. By participating, students will not only develop practical research skills but also contribute to addressing important societal issues, making this an impactful and enriching academic experience. Whether students are considering careers in economics, policy-making, or research, this course offers a unique opportunity to apply their knowledge to real-world challenges and make a difference.

Title: Molecular evolution of rhodopsin
Description:
The objectives of this project are to investigate the molecular basis of visual adaptations. The focus is on genes involved in the evolution of adaptations in key sensory systems such as the visual transduction pathway in photoreceptor cells of the eye. This project will involve both computational and experimental aspects, including the analysis of genomic datasets currently in the lab, as well as from publicly available databases, as well as molecular biology methods, including PCR and cloning methods.

Student Roles:
Students participating in this 299Y project would be involved in one or more avenues of research, depending on time and availability, with opportunities to be exposed to a diverse array of methodologies in the study the evolution of visual transduction genes, which can include:
1. Bioinformatics. Fundamentals of bioinformatics, including database mining, and comparative sequence analysis, as well as sequence editing, aligning, and primer design.
2. Computational biology. Basics of comparative sequence analyses such as phylogenetic analyses, and analyses of selective constraint.
3. Molecular methods. Basics of methodologies in molecular biology. These can include techniques such as gel electrophoresis, PCR, restriction digests, ligations, and miniprepping of plasmid DNA, in addition to fundamental skills such as making and autoclaving solutions and other media.
4. Lab participation and final report. Students would participate in lab meetings/journal clubs. Students would be expected to attend lab meetings, and present their results to the lab. They are expected to keep detailed notes with respect to dry/wetlab analyses, and to compile their results into a final report.
5. Participation in ROP poster fair. Students are expected to participate in the ROP poster fair to present their results.
